question: And I didn't tell Dupree that I'd give you your job back... All I said was that I'd be glad to talk to you if you said the right thing... Do you have something to say? Fella, what'd I tell ya? If you're not willing to give a little extra, Champion can't use you. Now... Do... you... have... something... to say?
answer: I want my job back, Mr. Giacomo. I need to work and I need a good job.

question: Is that all?
answer: No, that's not all... I need money so that I can pay my mortgage and eat... I need a house to live in and a place to raise children... I need to buy clothes so I can--

question: I'm sorry, fella, but I gotta get back to work...
answer: Ezekiel, Mr. Giacomo.

question: Hunh?
answer: My name is Ezekiel... Ezekiel Rawlins.

question: Who the hell is that, Joppy?
answer: Just somebody I know... A bidness man.

question: What kinda business?
answer: Oh, I don't ask him all that. He comes in here every so often looking for somebody to do a little job for him... He pays good.

question: In other words, he's a gangster.
answer: I didn't say that... But if there's a dollar laying in the street I don't think he'll let a little dirt stop him from picking it up. If you worried about making that house note this month, maybe you wanna pay him a call. All them pretty girls you be with ain't gonna buy you a house. Sound like he just wants you to keep your eyes open for somebody... He'll pay you whether you see anything or not... If it was me I'd take that man's money and go on about my bidness... Ain't nothin' to worry about.

question: When somebody tells me "Don't worry," I usually look down to see if my fly is open... I noticed Albright didn't bother to pay for his drink. DeWitt Albright reminded me of somebody I knew back in Houston. His name was Raymond Alexander but we called him Mouse... Mouse called hisself a businessman too. And I found out that I shouldn't be nowhere around when Mouse got down to his business... I learned that the hard way. No... Just leave the trees alone. I had moved to Los Angeles right after the war with three hundred dollars and the G.I. Bill... And I liked coming home to a place that was mine... According to President Truman I had that comin' to me 'cause I had fought in 'the good war' against Hitler in Europe... But that didn't mean a damn thing to a lotta white folks including the foreman on my job... So, here I was out of work needin' thirty-two dollars to pay the mortgage... That was three days pay on my old job -- and I had about three days to get it.
answer: What are you doing here?

question: I'm looking for, uh...
answer: We only take deliveries between nine and six...

question: No, no... I...
answer: Yes, we do! Now you'd better leave.

question: Uh... Albright!
answer: What?

question: I'm here to see Mr. Albright. DeWitt Albright!
answer: Where's your delivery?

question: I have an appointment -- I'm supposed to meet him.
answer: Did he give you a note to come in here after hours? Well, did he? Because if he didn't--

question: Forget it, man. Next time I see him I'll just tell him you wouldn't let me in.
answer: Hold on. Across that way to the left and down the stairs...

question: Hey, man! What's wrong with you? Keep your hands to yourself. I don't let no man feel on me like that.
answer: Easy. Leave it, Shariff. I just wanted to make sure he was solo. You guys can go now. Easy and I have some business. Have a seat, Mr. Rawlins.

question: Your friends, hunh?
answer: Like you, Easy. I need a little help? I give 'em a call... Drink?

question: Sure.
answer: One thing I like about working for myself... I always have a bottle on the table... You wanna drink with me? Fine. You don't? Door's right behind you... Joppy tells me you're a war hero... Said you went in with Patton. So, you want the job?

question: Depends on what kind of job. I don't want to get mixed up in nothing.
answer: Walk out the door in the morning, Easy, and you're mixed up in something. Only thing that matters is if you're mixed up to the top or not.

question: I mean I don't wanna get mixed up with the law...
answer: Neither one of us wants to get mixed up in that. That's just rich people trying to keep me and you in our place. I'm looking for somebody for a friend. Daphne Monet... fiance of Todd Carter, one of the richest men in town... Been gone for two weeks...

question: She leave him?
answer: Evidently... You know how it is with women, Easy... Happens to the best of us...

question: I ain't never heard of her before. I wouldn't know how to find a woman like that.
answer: That's a shame. See, Daphne has a predilection for the company of Negroes. She likes jazz and pigs feet and dark meat, know what I mean.

question: So you think she might be down in Watts.
answer: I'm sure of it. But I can't go looking for her myself because I'm not of the right persuasion, so to speak. I've been asking Joppy for over a week, but all he could do was introduce me to you.

question: What do you want me to do?
answer: Just get a location on her. Mr. Carter wants to make up with her...

question: That's all.
answer: That's all. One hundred dollars, and I pay in advance.

question: I just have to tell you where she is?
answer: That's right. And keep it, you know, confidential... Joppy tells me you used to frequent an illegal club down on Eighty- ninth and Central. Somebody saw Daphne there a few nights ago. You could start tonight.

question: Hey, Junior. What's goin' on?
answer: Not too much. But stick around.

question: You got a cigarette?
answer: Sure.

question: Damn! How do you smoke these things?
answer: Don't you hafta work tomorrow?

question: Naw. I got fired.
answer: The last time I heard these fellas playin' tonight was back in Houston, the night your ole buddy Mouse had to pull me up off your ass.

question: That's the way you remember it, hunh?
answer: Hell, that's the way it was. When you gonna admit that you helped Mouse kill old man Navrochet?

question: Aw, man, get off that. I ain't had nothin' to do with that. Boy, it's happenin' tonight. Where's all the white women at?
answer: I don't pay them white girls no mind.

question: Yeah... I bet you don't.
answer: That's right. Just like you didn't help mouse kill his stepfather.

question: Go on, man.
answer: Hey, Easy. Did you help him kill his stepbrother, too?

question: Sure. Sure.
answer: You know Benny just wants you to say you're sorry, Easy. And he'll give you your job back.

question: I'm a sorry man, all right. Any man without his paycheck is sorry.
answer: I got it, Easy. Your money ain't no good up in here.

question: Naw, Dupree. This one's mine--
answer: You sure? You the one outta work.

question: Hey, you goin' home, Odell?
answer: He used to play till the cock crowed. But that ole cock don't crow nearly so much now...

question: Think I'm gonna head out.
answer: You be sorry if you go.

question: I think I'd be more sorry if I stay...
answer: Daphne sleep by now. You can't get none of that tonight. You been telling everybody Dahlia, but her name is Daphne.

question: You know her?
answer: Throw him in there on the bed, Easy. Throwed him outta his place, 'cause he couldn't pay the rent. I shouldn't even let him sleep here.

question: Damn... I need a cigarette.
answer: That all you need?

question: Coretta, sun catch me tip-toein' out your door and no tellin' what your neighbors say...
answer: Dupree run through his money, fall asleep on me. And you just gonna walk out on me like I was dog food...

question: You got a man in the other room... Why don't you tell me 'bout your friend Daphne?
answer: Why you keep askin' 'bout her? Colored women ain't good enough for you no more?

question: What if he hears somethin'?
answer: Way he snorin'? Oh yeah, daddy. You hittin' my spot! Oh yeah... yeah! Oooh, that's just too good, Easy. I can't give up that much love, daddy, not the way things is.

question: What things?
answer: You know, Dupree's right there in the next room.

question: Forget about him! You got me goin', Coretta!
answer: But it ain't right, Easy. Here I am doin' this right in the next room and all you doin' is nosin' after my friend Daphne...

question: Daphne? Oh, yeah... I ain't after her, baby. That's just a job.
answer: What job?

question: Man wants me to find her.
answer: What man?

question: Who cares, what man? I don't want nobody but you...
answer: But Daphne's my friend-- Oh, baby. Oh, daddy, you hittin' my spot! Oh, yeah...

question: Where you goin', Sophie? Get away from there! Hello?
answer: Mr. Rawlins, I've been expecting your call.

question: What?
answer: I hope you have good news for me.

question: Mr. Albright, is that you?
answer: Sure is, Easy. What's shakin'?

question: I got what you want. She's with--
answer: Hold on to that, Easy. I like to look a man in the face when we do business. Meet me at the Fisherman's Pier in Malibu at the hamburger stand in an hour.

question: Yeah. It's all right. Huh?... Uh... Texas... The Gulf, they have the Gulf. I think they're looking for you.
answer: Hey! What's wrong? Hey, fella, what's wrong with you?

question: I don't want no trouble.
answer: You already got trouble, boy.

question: What do you want?
answer: I want to see brains. I want you to die for me.

question: I'm sorry, sir.
answer: The question is

question: Yessir.
answer: Then prove it... Show him... Get down on your knees and suck his peter.

question: Then prove it... Show him... Get down on your knees and suck his peter.
answer: I think he got the point--

question: You heard me. Son of a gun. You were gonna do it, weren't you? Sick bastard. Get out of here. You call the cops, I'll kill ya! I don't think they'd dare call the cops. But it'll cost me a few bucks if they do. What you got, Easy?
answer: You sure no harm is gonna come to that woman 'cause of me?

question: Course not. Mr. Carter wants to buy her a gold ring and live happily ever after -- What do ya got?
answer: Woman told me she's with a man named Frank Green.

question: Where?
answer: He's got an apartment at the Skyler Arms on Skyler and Eighty-third.

question: Anything else?
answer: Frank's a gangster. A hijacker... Liquor and cigarettes. He's real good with a knife.

question: Ever seen him in action?
answer: Naw. I just heard about him.

question: Here's another hundred. Buy ya a burger, Easy?
answer: No thanks, Mr. Albright.

question: How come you let those boys get around you like that? War hero should have been able to pick 'em off one by one before they got you against the rail.
answer: I don't kill children.

question: Take it easy.
answer: Yeah.

question: Where?
answer: You'll see.

question: You arresting me?
answer: You'll see.

question: I got a right to know why you're taking--
answer: You got a right to fall down and break your face, nigger. You got a right to die.

question: Yeah, we got him coming home. Nothing on 'im. Ezekiel Rawlins.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: We can take off the cuffs if you wanna cooperate.
answer: I'm cooperating.

question: Where were you this morning at about five A.M.?
answer: What do you mean?

question: Why, I'm gonna sit down and you keep trying to knock me down?
answer: Did you go back and see Miss James later in the day?

question: No, sir.
answer: Did you and Dupree Brouchard have words over Miss James?

question: Get up slow... Real fuckin' slow or you know what's gonna happen.
answer: Okay. Let's take him out back.

question: No. Let's go.
answer: Bullshit, I'm gonna blow his--

question: Let's go!
answer: Son-of-a-bitch! Son-of-a-bitch!

question: I don't have time right now.
answer: I can see that the police roughed you up a bit... That's a terrible practice of theirs which has to change, Mr. Rawlins... Has to change. She was beaten. And died from a heavy blow to the back of the head, Mr. Rawlins. The evening's events have caught my adopted son and I quite off guard... My household was asleep when we got the call that the police had a suspect in Coretta James' murder... Did you know that she was a friend of mine, Mr. Rawlins!?

question: No I didn't, Mr. Teran.
answer: Oh, you know who I am?

question: I read the papers. You're runnin' for mayor.
answer: I am the next mayor, Mr. Rawlins... And luckily for you, a friend of the Negro... When I arrived at the station I knew right off that you were being improperly detained as is Coretta's boyfriend, Dupree Brouchard. It's this sort of thing that my administration will not tolerate, Mr. Rawlins. Absolutely will not... Yes... Coretta answered phones for a while in my campaign office on 103rd and Western. In fact my people got her a job in the phone company. So when I heard what had happened I got out of bed immediately, personally because of my concern... Was anyone there with you Mr. Rawlins besides Mr. Dupree Brouchard?... Any... other friends of Coretta's?

question: No, sir...
answer: No young lady perhaps?

question: Nobody...
answer: Of course not, Mr. Rawlins. And why should you tell a man whom you've only just met. But, believe me, Mr. Rawlins. You can trust me.

question: There was no one else.
answer: Well don't worry, Mr. Rawlins... I won't tolerate your being harassed... You or any of my constituency -- I was a city councilman in the Watts area for two terms with a large contingent of colored -- I value all of my supporters equally... humble though they may be -- where can we drop you, Mr. Rawlins?

question: You can let me out here.
answer: Are you sure, Mr. Rawlins? This must be quite out of your way.

question: It's okay.
answer: Norman, pull the car over. Mr. Rawlins, may I offer you cab fare?

question: No thanks. There had been nights during the war that I still had trouble claiming as part of my life... Insane nights I wasn't sure ever really happened. And here I was again... Had I really just gotten out of a rich man's car who was runnin' for mayor?.. Running against the man I was supposed to be working for... Was he really lookin' for the same woman I was trying to find? My ear was killin' me and the buses had stopped running. And I was feeling sick... Sick from wondering if I had really hard that Coretta was dead. Huh? Who is this?
answer: You're looking for me. I think you should come and talk to me, Mr. Rawlins... alone.

question: Look, it's late--
answer: Mr. Rawlins, Coretta has been killed... And if you don't want any trouble from the police then you'll come... And you won't tell anyone that you're coming.

question: Now wait a minute, Daphne. I don't know nothin' about all this stuff...
answer: I'm at the Sunridge Motel on 112th and Grand, Room 102. Mr. Rawlins?

question: Yeah.
answer: Please come in. Would you like a drink?

question: No, thanks.
answer: Please sit down. What happened to you? Have you been fighting?

question: Why don't you just tell me what you want?
answer: I should be asking you that question. Why have you been asking about me?

question: I heard about you. Fellas at John's said you were something to see.
answer: So...? You've found me.

question: Uh... yeah... Guess I have. But you got a boyfriend I don't want no part of... Frank Green.
answer: You can stop pretending, Mr. Rawlins. I know someone hired you to look for me. In fact I had to pay Coretta not to tell you where I was... you know how Coretta is... She told me you two became 'good friends' yesterday... I talked to her this morning before she died. I... uh... need to go across town to see someone. It's very important... I can't seem to reach him by phone. I'm afraid I'd better have someone go with me.

question: Uh... Miss Monet--
answer: Call me Daphne.

question: Daphne--
answer: I can understand why you'd be nervous... because I threatened you with Coretta... I'm very sorry, but I couldn't think of any other way to get you to come.

question: I can't -- why don't you ask Frank?
answer: He's out of town -- I... I'm willing to pay you.

question: That's nice of you but, see, I'm not really a detective--
answer: --I know that.

question: I was just hired to ask around to try to find you for a man--
answer: I know all about that, Mr. Rawlins.

question: But this is a gettin' a little out of hand--
answer: --Mr. Rawlins--

question: --Easy.
answer: Easy... If you don't help me, then I'll call the police and tell them that you were with Coretta before she died and that you've been after me too.

question: You'd do that?
answer: Yes, I would. I don't want to but I would. Please let me pay you.

question: No. I can't do that.
answer: Why?

question: I don't want no part of all this.
answer: Please, I'll pay you twenty dollars.

question: No dice.
answer: Thirty... or even more. Name your price. Go ahead. There's gotta be something that you want. What? Are you afraid I'll yell rape or something?

question: Uh, Miss Monet... Daphne, I'm sorry but I really better be goin'.
answer: Easy, don't touch that door--

question: Crazy assed broad! What the hell are you doing?!
answer: I'm really very sorry. I really am. I didn't want to do this but... Shall we? They must not have seen us that well... God, Frank and I have been pulled over so many times I thought-- Easy, I'm sorry... Don't be mad at me. Come on. You really hate me, don't you?

question: How much further is it?
answer: Around the next bend... You remind me of Frank when he gets angry.

question: Ain't nothin' about me like Frank.
answer: Your jaw sets just like his when--

question: I don't get no kick outta risking my life for some white woman's entertainment.
answer: Just park behind the Studebaker. Did you bring a gun or something?

question: What? No.
answer: Easy, that's not very smart. Everybody carries a weapon now a days.

question: Well then where's yours?
answer: Search me sometime. You'll find it.

question: Damn...
answer: Mr. McGee... Oh, my God!

question: Daphne! Hey, wait a minute! Dammit!
answer: Easy.

question: What you doin' in my house, man?
answer: I expected you to be home, so Manny used a screwdriver on the door. What happened to your face?

question: You got no excuse to be breakin' into my house -- What if I broke into your place?
answer: I'd tear your nigger head out by its root.

question: So what do you want?
answer: Where have you been this time of morning, Easy?

question: I went to see a girl. Don't you get none, Mr. Albright?
answer: I didn't come here to play, boy. You got my money in your pocket and we've been over at that address waitin' all night for Frank Green and now we've found out that he moved from there over a year ago.

question: So what do you want me to do about it? You don't think I did my job. Shit, I give you the money back.
answer: Do you believe in God, Easy? 'Cause I'm curious to see if death is any different for a religious man.

question: I seen her.
answer: Where?

question: She called me. Had me drive up to the Hollywood Hills.
answer: How'd she know about you?

question: I guess Coretta... the girl that told me about Daphne and Frank Green.
answer: Why didn't you call me?

question: I couldn't. She threatened to tell the cops that I had killed Coretta...
answer: Where is she?

question: She took off.
answer: Where is she?

question: I don't know! While I was looking at the body she split.
answer: Uh-hunh. You call the cops?

question: I tried my best to keep in the speed limit. That's all I did.
answer: What'd she do, take his car?

question: Hunh?
answer: McGee. Did she take his car?

question: Uh... Yeah...
answer: Where'd you pick her up at?

question: She left that place--
answer: --Write it down! Get me some whiskey, Easy.

question: Get it yourself... Bottle's in the cabinet.
answer: Well, I'll be damned. Get us a drink, Manny... Easy, you're a brave man. I need a brave man working for me... But you gotta find Frank Green, so he can lead us to her.

question: No, thanks, Mr. Albright. People are gettin' killed all around me... You never said anything about all this...
answer: Easy, you're connectable to two murders. You'll do whatever I tell you to do. Now you got three days to find him. And you make sure you count 'em right.

question: I needed help... Albright didn't flinch at hearing that Coretta was dead and he seemed to know all about Richard McGee too... Raymond Alexander on... Forget about it, operator.
answer: Hey, Easy.

question: That girl called me last night.
answer: What girl is that?

question: The one your friend is lookin' for.
answer: Uh, huh. That's pretty lucky, hunh?

question: No, Joppy... Wasn't no luck at all. It was you. You and Coretta was the only ones that had my phone number who knew I was lookin' for her. And Coretta was busy scammin' Daphne so she wouldn't have done it... It was you, man.
answer: Maybe she looked in the phone book.

question: I ain't in the phone book, Joppy...
answer: What the hell you mean, coming up here all mad like you gonna do something?!...

question: You damn right! Coretta's dead! Your friend Albright is on my ass. The cops done brought me down once -- Why didn't you just tell Albright your damn self?
answer: What did I tell you? To just take that man's money! I didn't tell you to do nothin'! I call myself trying to help you save your house... Don't come up in here startin' no shit with me. Easy, wait! Watch my marble! My uncle left me that when he died!

question: And goddammit, he's about to get it back.
answer: Let's talk. Let's just talk.

question: What you got me into, Joppy?!
answer: She asked me to help her 'cause I told her that Albright was lookin' for her. And I figured I could help you make a few bucks and throw Albright off the trail too. She wanted to know something about you so I told her... I guess I must've give her your phone number...

question: Where is she, man?
answer: I don't know...

question: Don't lie to me, Joppy!
answer: I ain't lyin'... I don't even know her that good. She just asked me to help her. And she asked me not to tell nobody... I guess 'cause of her and Frank Green.

question: What's she runnin' from Joppy?
answer: I swear I don't know. She didn't tell me. I didn't mean to get you into nothin', Easy... I just... she just... I mean you seen her, Easy... Man, she's something else.

question: Damn, Joppy. Is there any white woman that ever gave you the time of day that you wasn't a sucker for? Albright had said that when you're mixed up in something it's best to be mixed up to the top. I could see his point. So that's where I was going... all the way to the top.
answer: May I help you?

question: Uh... yes. I came to see Mr. Carter.
answer: Do you have an appointment?

question: No, I don't.
answer: Well, I'm sorry, but Mr. Carter is a very busy man.

question: Well, tell him Mr. Albright sent me, and it's real important.
answer: May I ask the nature of your call, Mister...?

question: Rawlins. But I'm not so sure he'd want me to tell you.
answer: I'm quite sure, Mr. Rawlins, that whatever you know is nothing I can't know as well.

question: Okay. Well, anyway, tell him I'm here with information about that little chippy of his that dumped him.
answer: Is this some sort of joke?

question: Yes. Mister... I don't wanna hear it, man. It's too much goin' on for me to give a damn about what you think is smart.
answer: Mr. Rawlins. Has something happened to Daphne?

question: The last time I saw her she looked fine.
answer: You saw her?

question: Yeah. Last night.
answer: She's still in town?

question: She was last night.
answer: What did she say -- what was she wearing?

question: A blue dress. Blue heels.
answer: And a pin on her chest?

question: Yeah, on the left side.
answer: Oh yes, that's her. That's her. You know I've never known a woman who could wear perfume so slight that--

question: --Mr. Carter, Mr. Carter--
answer: What did she say? What did she say?... Oh, I'm sorry. Brandy?

question: Mr. Carter. I came here to get some answers.
answer: Yes...?

question: I don't know... I'm takin' a helluva chance... I guess it's just that when I'm working for somebody, I wanna know what I'm gettin' myself into...
answer: I beg your pardon.

question: Well, I'd like to know the real reason why Mr. Albright hired me.
answer: Mr. Albright?

question: Yeah. The man you hired to find Daphne.
answer: There must be some mistake... I'm sorry, busy... Who are you talking about?

question: You didn't hire somebody to find your girlfriend?
answer: No... Until just now I was sure that she was hundreds of miles away from here... You say someone is looking for her? Someone is looking for her.

question: What's goin' on between you two?
answer: Uh... I don't know... We were going to be married... We had a fight... Uh... that's none of your concern, Mr. Rawlins. Someone's... after her? A Mr. Albright? And he said he's working for me?

question: Yeah... Do you know a man named Richard McGee?
answer: No... I can't say that I do.

question: Why would someone be after her, Mr. Carter?
answer: Uh... I can't say -- I don't know... Do you think you could find her again?

question: I don't know.
answer: It's important, Mr. Rawlins, for her sake... I'm willing to pay you.

question: Mr. Carter, why did she leave?
answer: I can't tell you any more Mr. Rawlins -- I'll pay you to find her...

question: Okay... a thousand dollars.
answer: A thousand dollars?!

question: Yeah. I'll take two hundred right now.
answer: Mr. Rawlins. I think you're trying to take advantage of me. But left me inform you that the incumbent mayor and the chief of police eat at my house regularly.

question: Good. Then they can help us--
answer: --No. They can't!

question: Mr. Carter, why'd you stop runnin' for mayor?
answer: I'll have Baxter write you a check.

question: Why is Matthew Teran looking for her too?
answer: Baxter will write you a check!!

question: I'll take cash, Mr. Carter.
answer: Take it all... Just take it all.

question: Want me to kill him?
answer: Mouse! Aw, man naw, it's all right...

question: Well, what's happenin'? I'll blow your goddamned nose off...
answer: No, don't! Where's Daphne Monet? Look, if you don't know where she is, maybe we can help each other find her.

question: Nigga, you heard him.
answer: No, Mouse. Don't kill him.

question: Huh?... He's busy right now, you gonna have to call back.
answer: Frank, a rich man she knows is willing to pay a thousand dollars just to talk to her. A thousand bucks, man.

question: Easy, lemme try. You better... Talk... You stupid--
answer: Let him go!

question: Get out of my way!
answer: Let him be!

question: Damn you, Easy. Don't you never grab me when I got a gun in my hand! Look at the blood you done got on my coat. Why you wanna go and do that? Now we got to find that girl so we can get that money.
answer: No, we don't, Mouse. I don't need your kinda help or I would've called you.

question: You standing there with a knot on your head the size of a twelve- year-old tittie and you "don't need my kind of help"?
answer: This is the same shit you pulled five years ago when you asked me to drive you out to your stepfather's house, then come to find out you killed him and your stepbrother.

question: Aw, easy, that was a long time ago. Come on, Easy. Cut me in on this. I could help you. I let you run the show. I swear I will. I swear, I ain't gonna do nothin' you don't tell me to do.
answer: Everything I say?

question: Everything you say.
answer: Who was that called?

question: I don't know... Sound like some white girl. Hey, Easy, was it a left on Richland or a right?
answer: A right. And if Dupree ain't over there in Compton, just come on back 'cause I might have heard from the girl.

question: Mr. Rawlins... We came to ask you a few more questions.
answer: So why don't you just invite us inside... After you. What happened to your head? I don't remember doing all that.

question: Been having a party, Ezekiel?
answer: You got a lotta cuts and bruises to be an ordinary working stiff.

question: I ain't been there.
answer: Where?

question: I ain't been in no dead man's house.
answer: How 'bout a smoke, Ezekiel? Got a light? May I? Nice lighter... And we got our print.

question: What do you mean?
answer: Oh, hadn't you heard? We found a cigarette lighter in the dead man's house with the killer's fingerprints on it.

question: Naw, man. I didn't do it.
answer: Course you did, we got evidence.

question: I didn't do it. You know I didn't...
answer: We know that you know more than you're lettin' on. And now a white man's been killed. Now you better tell us what you know, or you're goin' down for the murder of Richard McGee and Coretta James.

question: I don't know nothin'.
answer: Put the cuffs on. Let's take him down.

question: Uh, listen! I don't know who did it!
answer: But we do...

question: Dammit, I didn't do it.
answer: Tell it to the D.A.

question: Look, gimme some time to find out.
answer: Forget it.

question: Gimme till tomorrow... Tomorrow mornin'...
answer: Okay. Tomorrow morning, that's it.

question: I guess you know what would have happened if you had shot them two cops in my house?
answer: Hell yeah. They'd be dead.

question: Come on, let's go.
answer: What they tryin' to pin on you?

question: I'll tell you on the way. You got the keys?
answer: Yeah.

question: I ain't got time now. I'm tryin' to get some sleep.
answer: Why don't you open the door, Junior, 'fore I have to shoot it down.

question: Mouse.
answer: Open up. We ain't got all night.

question: Y'all want a beer?
answer: What ya smokin'? Zapatas? This is one of yours, ain't it? You the only one I know cheap enough to smoke this shit... Why'd you kill Richard McGee?

question: Huh? What you talkin' 'bout?
answer: Ain't no time to play, Junior. I know you the one killed him.

question: Tell me what happened, Junior.
answer: I don't know what you talkin' 'bout.

question: Well, the police will. When they find out that they got your fingerprints up there in that man's house.
answer: What fingerprints? What house?

question: Hattie had you pull that man out of John's the night I was there. And he was laying up there dead with the same suit on and a knife in his chest.
answer: I ain't killed nobody.

question: Quit lyin', you big ole sweaty- thick headed-cornbread eatin'--
answer: You thick-headed, ya damn self!!

question: Hell, yeah. Then he asked me about that white girl you was askin' everybody about at the club. And I told him I seen her with Coretta... What the hell I care if he know?
answer: You tell him but you won't tell me.

question: I don't like your ass, Easy. And he gimme fifty dollars.
answer: Fifty dollars? Just to tell him you seen her with Coretta?

question: Naw. To deliver a letter.
answer: What letter?

question: How should I know? He just said to give it to her.
answer: And you knew where she was?

question: I didn't say that! I give it to Coretta to give it to her the next mornin'!
answer: You 'spect me to believe that? Why would he trust you to give it to the girl if it was worth fifty dollars?

question: 'Cause he had to blow town, fool!
answer: Why?

question: He didn't say!
answer: You better be tellin' the truth. Let's go, Raymond.

question: Yeah. Lula Mae made some 'fore she went to work. Why somebody wanna kill her like that? Why?
answer: I don't know, Dupree... I don't know... Did Coretta ever say anything to you about a letter she was keeping?

question: Letter? What kinda letter?
answer: For that white girl...

question: It's all right, big man... it's all right...
answer: Holy shi-it... I was as nauseated from fear as I was from what I saw... Pictures of a much younger Matthew Teran and children... innocent, helpless, naked children... I got it. Come on, I think that girl is gonna call again.

question: That Dupree is a good man, but he sure can't hold his liquor.
answer: You got your sails up pretty far too, Raymond.

question: You callin' me drunk?
answer: Well, you been puttin' it away along with him and--

question: If I was drunk could I do this? Ain't a man in Texas can outdraw me!
answer: Put it down.

question: Go on. Go for your gun. Let's see who gets kilt.
answer: I don't have a gun, Raymond. Come on, let's go.

question: You fool enough to go without a piece then you must wanna be dead.
answer: Let him go, Raymond... He done learned his lesson. If you kill him then he won't have got it.

question: He fool enough to call me out and he ain't even got no gun? I'll kill the motherfucker.
answer: Let him live, Raymond, and he be scared whenever you walk in the room.

question: Motherfucker better be scared. I kill a motherfucker. I kill him!
answer: The pictures were burnin' a hole in my pocket... I had no doubt that Albright had killed McGee... and that he had done it for Matthew Teran... But Teran hadn't known who killed Coretta. I was sure of that, too. For the first time I hated walking up to my house... I still didn't know if I could go to the police. But Albright was liable to be showing up in a few hours asking about Frank Green. I was thinking I oughta forget the girl and leave town, back to Houston or Galveston where they didn't know me too good. Shit! Damn!

question: The pictures were burnin' a hole in my pocket... I had no doubt that Albright had killed McGee... and that he had done it for Matthew Teran... But Teran hadn't known who killed Coretta. I was sure of that, too. For the first time I hated walking up to my house... I still didn't know if I could go to the police. But Albright was liable to be showing up in a few hours asking about Frank Green. I was thinking I oughta forget the girl and leave town, back to Houston or Galveston where they didn't know me too good. Shit! Damn!
answer: Are you all right? What happened?

question: Your boyfriend, Frank Green, threw a surprise party for me.
answer: I'm sorry, Easy... Easy, Coretta's boyfriend, Dupree, got out of jail today. And...

question: --I already have the pictures...
answer: Easy, I paid seven thousand dollars for those pictures. They belong to me.

question: Oh yeah? Matthew Teran may have somethin' to say about that.
answer: Easy, you wouldn't dare.

question: Try me. Who killed Coretta?
answer: I don't know -- I'll pay you for them. I'll give you a thousand dollars.

question: You gave Richard seven.
answer: Okay, I'll give you seven.

question: Where'd you get seven thousand dollars from?
answer: Never mind. I'll give it to you. Easy, please. They're very important to me.

question: Coretta's life was important to a few people too. What's say you tell me who killed her?
answer: Easy, honey, I don't know.

question: 'Honey?' Do Frank and Carter really fall for that stuff? Come on... You and Todd Carter have a fight and all of a sudden he doesn't wanna be mayor no more... You leave, he's worried but he can't even get his buddies in the police department to help him find you... And now you wanna buy some pictures of Teran. Why? 'Cause he's got some dirt on you.
answer: Easy, why don't you just take the money!

question: Is that what Frank told Coretta? Was she being too nosy? Or was she just being Coretta and trying to bargain up the price?
answer: Easy, please. How much do you want?

question: Tell me. Is Frank your husband or your pimp?
answer: Easy, put the phone down.

question: Why don't you try screaming again? 'Cause I bet police like white women with Negro boyfriends who hijack trucks...
answer: Easy, please.

question: I bet they like pimps, and whores, too, who scam rich white men like Carter runnin' for mayor.
answer: Easy, please, put it down...

question: And I'm sure they like it when these white girls tell their colored men to lay low 'cause they killed a woman over some pictures of another rich white man.
answer: Frank is my brother. We have different fathers. Mine is white... Frank doesn't even know that Todd and I broke up. So far I've kept him out of all this. See, Coretta's the only one out here in L.A. besides my brother who knew about me... And about a month ago she took a job working for, of all people, Matthew Teran. She made friends with one of the girls in the office who told her that she'd heard that Teran was a pedophile. And Coretta got carried away and told her that Todd Carter was engaged to a colored woman. She was sorry and didn't think it would get to Teran... but it did and he got a hold of my birth records.

question: Who killed her, Daphne?
answer: Todd and I broke up and I paid a guy for the pictures of Teran. But somehow Coretta got them.

question: Who killed her?
answer: It was an accident. Coretta and I were still mad at each other. I mean, she threatened to sell Teran the pictures.

question: Who killed her goddammit!?
answer: I just asked Joppy to go over and put a scare in her... It was an accident. Joppy said she pulled a knife and tried to dump hot water on him... God, I didn't mean to hurt anybody... It's just that with the pictures I can--

question: What? Marry Carter? Be white again?
answer: Don't judge me, Easy! Do you think I like pretending that I'm someone else? Do you know how I've been treated by people, colored and white, when I've tried to live as a colored woman in a colored community. Do you have any idea what any colored man whose ever been with me has had to go through? Don't you dare judge me! Come on, Easy. Help me. Come on, you know it's the right thing to do... You know if things were different what would happen between us.

question: I'll tell you what can happen between us. You get Carter to clear me up from all this and you can have your pictures. That's all that could have ever happened between us.
answer: Sure, baby. Of course, sweetheart...

question: Where are the pictures?
answer: I don't know.

question: Where are they?
answer: I wouldn't tell him! And I won't tell you!

question: Mouse... Get Dupree's car. Drive it to 78th and Central... The butcher shop. Hurry up. It had come to me in less time than it takes to think that Albright was taking Daphne someplace more isolated than that office building downtown... Someplace where there would be no witnesses... And I was being left alive to take the fall. Sorry, baby... Lemme give you twenty bucks for them stockings you got on. Gimme one of them guns you got. Start up my car. I'm comin' out fast. Come on, Joppy. Let's go! You heard me. I'll blow your head off! Don't follow me, goddammit!
answer: Easy, what the hell you--

question: Shut up! Drive this damn thing, Mouse! Albright's got the girl. He's gonna kill her. Where would he take her? And you better get it right.
answer: Man, I don't--

question: Don't fool with me, man!
answer: There's a cabin out in Malibu on Route 9...

question: Make a right, Mouse! You sure 'bout this place?
answer: I guess so. He's done this kinda thing out there before.

question: Easy, what's done got into you? Thought y'all was friends.
answer: He killed Dupree's girlfriend.

question: You lyin'.
answer: Naw.

question: Son-of-a-bitch!
answer: Mouse! What're you doin'? Hey! Watch out! Mouse, we need him to lead the way! Mouse, the girl offered me seven thousand dollars for the pictures.

question: You lyin'!
answer: No, I swear I'm not.

question: Aw shit! Oh, my God!... Oh, my goodness! Oh, my goodness!
answer: Is that it up there?

question: Is that it up there?
answer: Yeah, that's it.

question: Shut off the headlights, Mouse. Is that it?
answer: Naw. It's farther up.

question: How much farther?
answer: Another ten minutes, I guess. Easy, I swear, I ain't done nothin' to nobody. I swear, I ain't. There it is.

question: There's some rope in the trunk, Raymond.
answer: Easy, come on, man. That girl is lying if she told you I killed them folks.

question: Damn, damn, damn! I hit him! I hit him!
answer: Come on... You all right?

question: There's blood all over here... I got him. Damn. Sweetheart. She okay?
answer: Yeah. Let's go. Where's Joppy? What happened?

question: I didn't have time to be tying him up.
answer: Why, man? Why?

question: Why what? You just said don't shoot him. And I didn't... I choked his ass...
answer: Damn Mouse! Why?

question: How I'm gonna help you back there foolin' 'round with him?
answer: He was tied up! Why?!

question: Aw, man. If you didn't want him kilt you shouldn't have left him with me.
answer: I convinced Mouse to take the two o'clock train to Pomona and to let me handle everything else. He could get a train back to Houston later that morning... He was fine with that but only because he was seven thousand dollars richer. Daphne had gotten the money out of a locker at the YMCA without a word... Because she was still in shock and couldn't really talk... Maybe too because she had stolen about four times that much from Carter.

question: Listen, if you think you gonna have trouble with that dude Frank, I can run by and kill him and take that evening train to Houston.
answer: Naw, man.

question: Oh. This is for you. I cut you in for half 'cause I knew you was too big a fool to take your share from that white girl yourself. Send my grip to Etta Mae. I'm gonna see if she'll take me back now that I'm flush. Oh, here's the keys to Dupree's car. And if you need somebody to run them streets with ya, gimme a call. You know how to put some money in a nigga's pocket.
answer: I knew I would see him again and I didn't know how I felt about that... 'cause, unlike Mouse, my legs were like rubber... the way they had been in the war the whole two years I was there. I could tell how it was gonna go when Carter asked us to meet him at the Observatory instead of at his house... She knew it, too. But she had come this far and she had to play it out.

question: You got some mighty powerful friends up there... mighty powerful. But, see, we got a problem. With the Chief sealing these things up like this, it doesn't do much for the morale of the men who've been working on these cases.
answer: Yeah. Makes 'em feel like shit.

question: There's a guy who's been callin' on the phone. And we're pretty sure that he was up there with McGee.
answer: A... uh... colored guy... sounds kinda dumb...

question: Not very bright... But he said you accused him of the murder. And he swears you were up there, too...
answer: In fact, he's out and out pointing the finger at ya.

question: How about a name?
answer: He'd do it to you...
